text:
Why doesn't this work, since `1.2 isa Number` ?
```julia> using Dates

julia> struct FloatOf{T} <: AbstractFloat end

julia> FloatOf{Date}(1.2)
ERROR: MethodError: no method matching FloatOf{Date}(::Float64)
Closest candidates are:
  FloatOf{Date}(::Real, ::RoundingMode) where T<:AbstractFloat at rounding.jl:200
  FloatOf{Date}(::T) where T<:Number at boot.jl:716
  FloatOf{Date}() where T at REPL[50]:1
  ...
Stacktrace:
 [1] top-level scope at REPL[51]:1```

elements.text:
julia> using Dates

julia> struct FloatOf{T} <: AbstractFloat end

julia> FloatOf{Date}(1.2)

text: Can we cross post this publicly to <https://discourse.julialang.org|Discourse> for further visibility? React with :bridge: on the message above to approve. <https://github.com/JuliaCommunity/SlackBridge/blob/main/README.md#faq|More info here>
`FloatOf` is a singleton, it has no fields, what do you expect `FloatOf{Date}(1.2)` to do?

elements.text: is a singleton, it has no fields, what do you expect

text: I want an instance of FloatOf{Date} with value 1.2

elements.text: I want an instance of FloatOf{Date} with value 1.2

text:
> FloatOf is a singleton, it has no fields, what do you expect FloatOf{Date}(1.2) to do?
:point_up:

elements.text: FloatOf is a singleton, it has no fields, what do you expect FloatOf{Date}(1.2) to do?

text: Float64 doesn't have fields either, but Float64(1.2) works

elements.text: Float64 doesn't have fields either, but Float64(1.2) works

text:
1. Float64 is a primitive type, not a singleton
2. `Float64(1.2)` is doing the conversion of `1.2` to `Float64`, which is no-op since `1.2` is already `Float64`

elements.text:
1. Float64 is a primitive type, not a singleton
2.

text: perhaps you want to add a field to your datastructure?  it doesn't have any "value" otherwise, there is only a single instance possible (for each parameter)

elements.text: perhaps you want to add a field to your datastructure?  it doesn't have any "value" otherwise, there is only a single instance possible (for each parameter)

text: I want something that behaves in every way like a float, just with a custom type name

elements.text: I want something that behaves in every way like a float, just with a custom type name

text:
then yes, you need to do
```struct FloatOf{F<:AbstractFloat,T} <: AbstractFloat
    val::F
end```
and define all operations you need for your type
